text: I believe OCP has been making donations
to African countries as well of fertilizers.
Can you can you say some words about that?
Again, you have to put this in the backdrop of
what we have done over the past
8-10 years in Africa, which is customize the fertilizer

working locally to formulate
also the right type of fertilizer

and not just the right type
but the right practices,

not applying all the nutrients
at the same time, so on and so forth.
Then, you know, if you recall,
this is almost a year,

a bit past a year since
the Ukraine war started.
And at that point,
in early March-April of last year,
there was a panic,

almost a panic movement on fertilizer,
because some of the fertilizer was coming

from Russia to Africa, mainly,
but also to Europe.

And even with the natural gas worries
in Europe - the nitrogen based
fertilizer companies were very worried
not to get the feedstock - the gas.

I believe even a few fertilizer
factories closed,
stopped production.
So there was a -
this could have been a catastrophe

for some of the African countries
that were importing fertilizer.

So at that stage,
also the nitrogen prices

were going through the roof
because of the gas prices, if you recall.

And so this reached way
beyond the affordability
point for some African farmers,
the small farmholders.

The individual African
farmers, could not afford fertilizer.
So what we did is a program of donation
targeted to the smallholder
in various African countries.

I forgot how many,
but probably a good 20 countries.
We've done targeted donations of fertilizer,

usually the customized
fertilizer by the way.
